G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A, 21..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum amount required for civil jurisdiction in the District Court Department, exclusive of interest and costs, but does not exceed the jurisdictional maximum.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8..proposition: Venue is proper in the Newton Division of the District Court Department because the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability of risk. This is framed as a broad common-law duty, not limited to the specific firearm-storage facts of the case, and is supported by citation to prior Massachusetts authority and the Restatement. That aligns with the claimed proposition about a general duty to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm to others.
*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states, as a general principle of tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing the Restatement (Second) of Torts. Although the case ultimately recognizes an exception for a pregnant woman toward her fetus, it clearly affirms the broad common-law duty of reasonable care to avoid creating foreseeable risks of physical harm to others. Thus, it supports the proposition as a statement of the general rule, even while carving out a specific limitation.
*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.relevant_excerpt: "Whether a duty exists is a question of common law... As a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 302 comment a (1965) ('In general, anyone who does an affirmative act is under a duty to others to exercise the care of a reasonable man to protect them against an unreasonable risk of harm to them arising out of the act')."

*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..proposition: Owners and keepers of dogs in Massachusetts owe a duty to use reasonable care in controlling and restraining their dogs so as to prevent foreseeable injury to others lawfully on public or private property.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..support_reasoning: The case expressly distinguishes statutory strict liability for dog owners/keepers from common‑law negligence, and it emphasizes that, at common law, even an owner or keeper of a dog is not liable absent knowledge (or reason to know) of the dog’s dangerous propensities and some fault. The opinion does not articulate a general duty on dog owners/keepers to use reasonable care to control or restrain dogs to prevent foreseeable injury to lawful entrants; instead it treats dogs as ordinarily harmless and rejects liability without notice of danger. Thus it does not support the broad negligence duty stated in the proposition.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Apart from statute even an owner or keeper of a dog, as our cases recognize, is not liable for bodily injuries inflicted by it in the absence of proof that he knew, or at least should have known, its dangerous propensities … and in the absence of proof of some fault of such owner or keeper. … Where, as in the present case, no statute intervenes, the liability for bodily injuries caused by dogs falls within the general principles governing liability for injuries caused by animals ordinarily harmless.”

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: That general duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to comply with applicable statutes, ordinances, and posted rules concerning the control, restraint, and leashing of dogs in public places, and to avoid conduct that creates an unreasonable risk that others will suffer physical harm.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns dram shop liability and clarifies that violation of an alcohol-serving statute (§ 69) is only some evidence of negligence and does not constitute negligence per se. It does not discuss dogs, leashing, or animal-control statutes, nor does it frame a general duty of care specifically in terms of compliance with such statutes or posted rules. While it recites the general negligence standard (unreasonable risk of harm), it does not establish the more specific proposition about dog control obligations in public places.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se... Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.... The key question for the jury to answer, therefore, is, did the defendant... take... an unreasonable risk which the ordinarily prudent proprietor would have refrained from taking."

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: That general duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to comply with applicable statutes, ordinances, and posted rules concerning the control, restraint, and leashing of dogs in public places, and to avoid conduct that creates an unreasonable risk that others will suffer physical harm.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises and contractor negligence arising from a scaffolding collapse, focusing on duty, control, and causation. It does not address dog ownership, animal control, leashing, or any statutes, ordinances, or posted rules about control or restraint of dogs in public places. Consequently, it cannot be authority for the specific duty-related proposition about dog control and compliance with such dog-related regulations.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: "With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof."

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 136A\u2013174F.proposition: The City of Newton, pursuant to G.L. c. 140, §§ 136A–174F, and its municipal home rule authority, has adopted ordinances and regulations requiring that dogs in public parks and on public ways be restrained or leashed, and the Park where this incident occurred was posted with signs expressly requiring all dogs to be on leashes.

*Kaneshiro v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 354 Mas.proposition: Violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation designed to protect the public can constitute evidence of negligence in Massachusetts.
*Kaneshiro v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 354 Mas.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is from a criminal case concerning double jeopardy, jury instructions (the Tuey/Allen charge), voluntariness of statements, and sufficiency of evidence for degrees of murder. It does not discuss negligence, civil liability, or the evidentiary effect of violating a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation. Accordingly, it cannot be authority for the proposition that such violations constitute evidence of negligence in Massachusetts.
*Kaneshiro v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 354 Mas.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the reproduced opinion addresses safety statutes, ordinances, regulations, or their role as evidence of negligence in a civil action. The case instead focuses on issues of double jeopardy, jury instructions, intoxication, and criminal procedure in a murder prosecution.

*Richards v. Warren*, 366 Mass. 782, 786.proposition: Violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation designed to protect the public can constitute evidence of negligence in Massachusetts.
*Richards v. Warren*, 366 Mass. 782, 786.case_name: McCarthy v. Sheriff of Suffolk County
*Richards v. Warren*, 366 Mass. 782, 786.support_reasoning: The opinion in Richards v. Warren concerns the constitutionality of a statute lowering the mandatory retirement age for court officers and addresses issues of retroactivity, contract impairment, due process, and equal protection. It does not discuss negligence, tort law, or the evidentiary effect of violating safety statutes, ordinances, or regulations. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that violation of a safety enactment can constitute evidence of negligence in Massachusetts.
*Richards v. Warren*, 366 Mass. 782, 786.relevant_excerpt: Examination of the various groups established by the statute discloses a legislative intent to provide for earlier retirement of those government officers concerned with the safety of the public. Thus, the statute provides for the early retirement of State police officers, and other law enforcement personnel and those employed in positions involving potential danger to the safety of the public are also classified in groups having an earlier retirement age than that of general officials and employees.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that allowing a large dog to run loose and to charge at a person on a jogging path could cause that person either to be physically struck or bitten by the dog or, alternatively, to take sudden evasive action (such as swerving, jumping, or running off the path) and thereby suffer injury from a fall or collision with some hazard in the vicinity.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focusing on causation and reasonable foreseeability in the context of Lombardo’s negligence, but it does so only to state that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm. It does not involve, discuss, or analogize to the situation of a large dog running loose and causing someone to take evasive action and be injured. Therefore, this opinion does not provide authority for the specific foreseeability proposition about loose dogs and evasive maneuvers causing injury.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for all harm that is within the scope of the foreseeable risk created by his conduct, including harm that occurs when an injured person takes reasonable evasive action to avoid an immediate perceived threat.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly endorses the general Massachusetts rule that an original negligent actor remains liable for harms that are the foreseeable consequence of the risk created, even when a third party’s conduct intervenes. However, the facts do not involve an injured person taking evasive action; the plaintiff is struck when the forklift turns toward her, not while she takes reasonable evasive steps. Thus, the case supports the foreseeability/scope-of-risk aspect of the proposition but does not itself address the specific sub-point about injuries occurring during evasive action.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.raw_text: *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902–03 (1987)
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for all harm that is within the scope of the foreseeable risk created by his conduct, including harm that occurs when an injured person takes reasonable evasive action to avoid an immediate perceived threat.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on general foreseeability limits on negligence and holds that the particular accident (a runaway vehicle injuring restaurant patrons) was not reasonably foreseeable and thus outside the defendant’s duty. It does not address, adopt, or discuss any rule about liability for injuries sustained when a person takes reasonable evasive action in response to an immediate perceived threat. The cited language is about the scope of foreseeable risk in premises liability, not about the specific doctrinal point regarding evasive action by an injured person.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.relevant_excerpt: “Proximate cause does not require the particular act which caused the injury to have been foreseen, only that the general character and probability of the injury be foreseeable. Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). But the court will not hold the defendant liable for all possible injury no matter how remote or farfetched. The cause of the injury must be reasonably foreseeable. There is no duty owed when the risk which results in the plaintiff’s injury is not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant.”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987)
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: That Plaintiff’s injury ultimately resulted from her fall over an exposed tree root and down a small embankment does not break the chain of causation.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with whether the employer’s conduct was a superseding cause that cut off the manufacturer’s liability for the hand injury caused by the machine. It does not discuss any later injury from a fall over an exposed tree root or down an embankment, nor any analogous subsequent accident. Accordingly, it cannot be authority for the specific chain-of-causation proposition described.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a tortfeasor is liable ‘for the foreseeable intervening conduct of a third party whether that conduct is negligent or not.’ Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 352 n.10 (1983), quoting Wilborg v. Denzell, 359 Mass. 279, 285 (1971). Grauel, as the designer of the product, was in the best position to recognize and eliminate design defects.”

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: That Plaintiff’s injury ultimately resulted from her fall over an exposed tree root and down a small embankment does not break the chain of causation.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether an intervening fall over a tree root and down an embankment breaks the chain of causation. Kent v. Commonwealth does not involve any such facts; it addresses whether the parole board’s 1987 release decision was the proximate cause of a 1995 shooting, and it ultimately finds that intervening actions by the INS were a superseding cause that broke the chain of causation. Thus, the case is about proximate cause in a very different factual context and does not support the specific proposition regarding a fall over a tree root and embankment.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events have broken the chain of factual causation or, if not, have otherwise extinguished the element of proximate cause and become a superseding cause of the harm. … Subsequent action by the INS releasing MacNeil in Massachusetts became a superseding cause of the harm he inflicted, relieving the Commonwealth of liability as a matter of law.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent Plaintiff’s own conduct is alleged to have contributed to her injuries, any such comparative negligence is minimal and, in any event, does not exceed fifty percent of the total negligence that proximately caused her injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 85K.proposition: Medical Expenses: Approximately $2,500 in past medical bills related to emergency room treatment, diagnostic imaging, and follow‑up care for her broken wrist, and the reasonable value of any future medical care that may be required.

*Vassallo v. Baxter Healthcare Corp.*, 4.proposition: Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all her damages proximately caused by his negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Vassallo v. Baxter Healthcare Corp.*, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts products-liability decision that affirms negligence and Chapter 93A liability and discusses standards for expert evidence and failure-to-warn doctrine. It does not address the general remedial rule that a negligent defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, nor does it articulate or apply any specific rule about the scope of recoverable damages. Thus, it does not provide authority for the broad damages proposition stated.
*Vassallo v. Baxter Healthcare Corp.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: "3. The evidence warrants the jury’s findings (and their verdicts) on the negligence claims, and the defendants’ arguments seeking judgment in their favor or a new trial on the negligence claims have been considered and rejected. No issue is raised as to the amount of damages awarded."
